SE 181.fullName: Introduction to Software Engineering and Development
SE 181.courseDesc: Introduces advanced software development fundamentals including memory management, typing and scoping, datastores, software testing, and security, as well as user-centric design and user experience. This course will be taught using a specified programming language of instruction.

SE 201.fullName: Introduction to Software Engineering and Development
SE 201.courseDesc: Introduces advanced software development fundamentals including memory management, typing and scoping, datastores and software testing. This course will be taught using a specified programming language of instruction.

SE 210.courseDesc: Study of the principles, practices, and techniques used to gather system requirements and document them in a requirements specification. Includes techniques for requirements discovery such as user interviews and prototyping. Introduces approaches for organizing and expressing software requirements in a requirements specification.

SE 211.courseDesc: Continues study of requirements with increasing emphasis on converting requirements into a software system design. Presents alternate approaches, techniques for evaluating specifications, specification and design tools, and use of specifications to develop system-level tests.

SE 310.courseDesc: Study of the principles and practices of object-oriented design with an emphasis on object relationships, loose coupling, and design patterns.
SE 310.prereqs: CS 265 [Min Grade C] and CS 260 [Min Grade C] and (SE 181 [Min Grade C] or SE 201 [Min Grade C])

SE 311.courseDesc: Continues discussion of software architecture with a focus on micro-level architecture including patterns, frameworks, and component-based software engineering, and commercial off-the-shelf software.

SE 320.courseDesc: Presents theory and practice of software testing. Covers structural testing including such topics as path testing, dataflow testing, logic based testing, syntax testing, program slicing, mutation testing, fault injection, program perturbation, and testing tools. Discusses techniques for test construction and test suite evaluation, and validation against requirements and design models. Also covers methods of inspection and review at various phases of the software lifecycle.
SE 320.prereqs: CS 260 [Min Grade C] and (SE 181 [Min Grade C] or SE 201 [Min Grade C])

SE 410.courseDesc: Covers issues related to change in software systems. Addresses principles and techniques of corrective software maintenance, software enhancements, and software product family. Introduces students to issues of change in large software systems including configuration control, change and product management.

SE 420.courseDesc: Explores tools, techniques, process, and culture of free and open source software (FOSS) projects. Addresses open source project evaluation, business models, and FOSS as a source of software engineering innovation. Includes student participation in an existing humanitarian FOSS project. Introduces concepts of computing for social good.

SE I199.courseDesc: Self-directed within the area of study requiring intermittent consultation with a designated instructor.
SE I199.repeatStatus: Can be repeated multiple times for credit
